I was sure enough about some answers (conDO, MIca, LActo, a FAvor, and entREe) that I recognized the theme fairly easily.  I had RAREGAS (because of the downs) but couldn't make any sense of it...I was making it three syllables and putting the accent on the second!

Hey, Daniel Finan, thanks for that fun puzzle. Very imaginative. Nicely done.

I'm probably not the best person to make this argument, but I doubt constructors are the only ones who like puzzles like this. I'm not sure why some comments are made every time the rules are stretched. Fwiw, I felt the difficulty level was just right for Thursday.

I haven't had a chance to dine at C&S yet, but I have eaten at all of Tom's NYC restaurants, including the Quilted Giraffe when he was there. For the most part his food and service are often very good and, at times, border on excellent. I'm looking forward to eating at his new restaurant.

I like serious restaurant reviews, but I like Sam's mix of metaphors that make you smile, while still providing the seriousness necessary for a well-written review. Lighten up. Sam probably travelled to the Far East and smelled opium. I doubt he's an addict. Also, 'foodies' often learn to sniff all kinds of odors and smells to help them isolate the tastes.

Either I'm missing something here, or the Across Lite version of today's puzzle is.  According to the version I'm filling in, 63D only has 3 spaces and 57A only has 4.  Linda G #9 has the answers I wanted to put in those spots, but they're not fitting.

3 stars? You've gotta be kidding! I ate there a month ago and couldn't have been more disappointed. Two waiters recommended three dishes that were not on the menu. I took the suggestion of the second waiter to have the urchin and crab fondue, which I was told "sounded like it might be goopy, but isn't". Well, it was a big goopy mess - blech! Think cheez whiz with canned crab.

Then the overcooked monkfish in vinegar, urr I mean black cabbage with vinaigrette. The vinegar was so overpowering one couldn't distinguish what type of fish it was.

Dessert was totally forgettable.

C'mon Sam - I'd like to support your reviews, but you missed the mark terribly with this one - maybe you went on a (few?) lucky night(s)???
I,m sure the food is excellent, could they just put a little more on the plates?

I think that people that go to "celebrity chef" restaurants deserve all the disappointment they can swallow. When the boss is not behind the range, your chances for a good or great meal is extremely poor. Colicchio and Sons is mediocre at best and overpriced for sure. The only restaurant I would go to that has a cook absent is McDonalds, who is not even a celebrity chef, or is he?

I recently attended a rather expensive and exclusive Tom Colicchio dinner at the esteemed James Beard Foundation in honor of the opening of this new restaurant. I consider myself a serious foodie, a fan of Top Chef, and until that dinner, a fan of Tom Colicchio and all he has done for the emergence of the NY dining scene. However, at this small intimate and expensive dinner, Tom did not even have the courtesy to mingle with guests, participate in cooking the meal, or even have the courtesy to stay for the dinner. In fact, in his opening remarks all he really did was remind all the guests how very lucky WE were to be in his presence and in fact he didnt even want to show up....he is just too busy these days. Myself and the guests at my table were all rather insulted. And to add insult to injury the meal was mediocre at best. To be expected I guess since Tom only stayed for about 15 minutes. To say the food served was unimaginable, poorly executed and just plain bland is being nice. I am officially boycotting Tom's restaurants and I urge you too as well. There are so many amazing chefs and restaurants in this city....which are operated by chefs that actually care about the dining experience in their restaurants and are appreciative of your patronage. Please go spend your hard earned money somewhere it is appreciated…..and where the food is better.

I want to elaborate on the 'wire floor' section. There is a particular type of wire that is suitable for rabbits. It is 1 inch long by 1/2 inch wide. Regular 1/2 inch x 1/2 inch hardware cloth is not suitable. Look up a reputable cage company such as BASS or Klubertanz in order to see what a good cage set up looks like.

As to the offense taken by a small minority of the readership, I'd like to say that not every rabbit is born to be a pet. These are commercial typed rabbits that are grown for meat. There are many breeds that are more suitable as pets, but they too are edible. Rabbits are livestock, just as a cow, pig, chicken or sheep. Rabbits are wonderful because they are a multi-purpose animal. I know some people keep them as pets, but it is not disgusting to be able to raise your own meat supply. . I doubt I'd be replying to a vegetarian article complaining about how they grow the carrots or upset that there is no meat on the menu.
It is good that people are taught how to grow and produce their own food. Personally, I'd rather not leave my food production entirely to big business.

If you don't like the content of an article or something on a blog, then may I suggest you turn the page or hit the little 'x' in the corner that closes it. Why do you get to censor the material I happen to find educational and enjoy reading? A newspaper writes for people from many different backgrounds and beliefs. So to the editors, please keep up this type of content. Being honest about where meat comes from and how it gets to us is not a crime.

I think this is great - I loved this when I lived in LA - it was great knowing that an A+ Mom & Pops restaurant have the same standards as a Zagat or Michelin rated restaurant.

I do have some concerns on the statement" The restaurant association had lobbied the health department to exempt all nonfood-related violations — like burned-out light bulbs, leaky faucets and improperly posted signs — from the letter-grade calculation."

Is there a definitive list of what violations were removed? I think that any restaurant that voluntarily submits to nonfood criteria and passes, that restaurant should not just receive an A, but an A-PLUS & GOLD STAR.

Mr. Sifton's experience at Colicchio & Sons was SO different from mine and everyone I know who's eaten there that I can only conclude that he was recognized. I found the food there sufficiently mediocre that two stars would have been a stretch. A major disappointment.

What's interesting is that my friends' and my experience is backed up by EVERY OTHER review that Colicchio & Sons has received. Does Mr. Sifton make himself aware of other reviews (only AFTER he's reached his own conclusion, one hopes)? Does anyone think that such a divergence from the critical consensus should be explained? (I'm not saying it's self-evident it should: that's a genuine question.)

Sam - My wife and I have had a few entanglements with the Collichio family -- all of them wonderful. First, and very much formative, we lived in NY just as wichcraft was opening—and though to some it may have dropped a few bars—I still foam at the mouth at the mere thought of his meatloaf sandwich. Pure double-bread brilliance! ON a cold winter Saturday, wichcraft was our haven. Then my wife took a job with another talented personality who has also spent some time with the Bravo family. And on one lovely Saturday evening here in LA, we mentioned as much to Tom as he came around our table in Craft LA. The conversation, and the food, made for a truly lovely evening. My glowing is only meant to convey one real truth -- Tom knows food, and Tom is old-school gentleman. His affable personality fills the dining room, and his ego always seems to be checked at the door. I appreciate his humility and approachability in an age when so many celebrity-whats-its seem to be utterly convinced of their own immortality and greatness. Talent takes on talent, and though he may have a lot going on, I can only hope that he pays as much attention to building a world-class support staff as he does his food. If that be the case, and though everyone slides from time to time, I wish him, and his family all the best of luck as they continue to bring contemporary, familiar, delicate, fanciful food to us foodies.Cheers!

It is about time!

I can't tell you how many times I have gotten sick from food at ostensibly "clean" restaurants--and I CHECK the Health Department's on-line restaurant inspections.

The LETTER-grading system--requiring them to post their grades prominently--preferably in the windows--is a welcomed improvement on the otherwise "hidden" (hard to find out) city inspection reports of these restaurants' kitchens. As things already stand, I don't understand how or why the health department hasn't shut down some of the persistently dirty restaurants! Now, the customers can shut them down by going elsewhere if the restaurants don't have acceptable letter grades representing clean kitchens.

I saw the same signage (in the windows of restaurants in California--and loved the system! I only ate in places with "A" grades in their windows.

Mike White, the restaurant owner here, is right--why should restaurant owners not welcome and embrace these letter grade postings?! What is there to fear unless there is something terribly wrong in their kitchens?!

The new system will only keep the restauranteurs on their toes!

At the same time, I doubt letter grades less than A will deter young people from frequenting those fast food places and pizza joints and such that resemble pit stops. Perhaps teens have iron stomachs--I do not! Three cheers to the NYC Department of Health for this advancement!

If lawsuits are to follow, then the New York City Council should pass a law that is needed--for a change--to ensure that this new letter grade reporting and posting regulation has the force and the support of law.

Michael Meyers, Manhattan, New York

I have stayed 4 nights at Ambassador Hotel Sultanahmet Istanbul and really loved it. I booked the hotel directly and paid with cash money upon arrival, which gave me some discount. They arranged free pick up from the airport, and since I arrived at 7.30AM that was wonderful. I was warmly welcomed by Benjamin, and immediately felt at home. All staff members are very friendly and helpful. I stayed at room 303 which was perfect. Big room, nice double bed (as a single traveler, i loved that!) and clean bathroom. Breakfast was good and enough varieties. Staff was very helpful in advising for the daily program and also about customs and do’s and don’ts in Istanbul. Istanbul for me (as a single woman traveler) was very safe. I didn’t feel uncomfortable at all. Istanbul is a wonderful city, but for sure also visit Taksim in the European area. Nice restaurants, pubs and young people. A visit to Gulhane park is also very nice. Don’t forget to drink some Turkisch tea at the back side of the park. Nice view!
I didn’t like my visit to Cemberlitas hamam. Too touristic!
But Ambassador, yes, I would definitely stay there again. Nice hotel, clean rooms, friendly staff who give you personal attention

Augwhite: thanks.  I realized after I posted that I should look at Ocean temps instead if I want the big picture.  Nonetheless, I enjoy anomaly charts and think them useful.  There was a great one showing the spectacularly warm Canadian winter compared to the cold US one.

For more on the question of tipping points, have a look at this post and the linked print article from last year:
http://j.mp/dotTip

A couple of quick points - first, the science - and I have read quite a bit of realclimate, have a strong undergrad science background, etc:
1) Tipping points - people keep bringing this up, but given that we've seen exactly zero tipping points with 1 degree of temp. increase in the last hundred years, doesn't this provide strong evidence against tipping points showing up with another 2 degrees of warming?

2) People keep comparing global warming to evolution, or smoking causing cancer. Yet in many ways the discussion seems more like the "does abstinence education result in a decrease or increase in teen pregnancies debate". Yes, people call it science, and have reports, and data, and in-depth statistical studies. Yet, you see a lot of people pushing data into SPSS until they see a result they like, then publishing it.

While all leads into the debate issues:
3) Among non-scientists on both sides of the debate, it seems that almost with fail, people are ideologically driven on this issue - if you believe the US hegemony is bad for the world, that oil and coal companies are destroying the environment, that we are rushing towards a cataclysmic future - well, you almost assuredly believed that before you knew anything about global warming. If you believe in free enterprise, technological solutions, distrust governments in general, well you probably felt that way before as well.

I would encourage anyone to really dig into the actual data sets being used for the 1000 year+ reconstructions, see how many physical locations they represent, what the uncertainties are, etc. Don't just take a few sentences from the paper's conclusion - look at the actual data sets. For example, how many 1000 yr+ proxies do we have for the Southern Hemisphere, half the world?

If another few degrees of warming will do such major damage to the world, surely we must have some examples of damage already done by the degree of warming we've experienced.

Where are they?

For more on the question of tipping points, have a look at this post and the linked print article from last year:
http://j.mp/dotTip

My concern is that unsophisticated and agenda driven scientists will lead people and nations to waste trillions of dollars on a potential problem that will be easily solvable by technological intervention if warming does occur and if it does cause substantial problems. Julian Simon has clearly demonstrated the power of and speed of human invention, which will surely be able to easily ameliorate any harmful effects of carbon dioxide 100 years from now. The idea that humans can make costly changes now that will be useful 100 years from now is ludicrous.

JD

"It will be especially awful if we are currently entering another "flat" zone in the climbing heat cycle, similar to ca. 1940-1970."

Of course, Len, let's set the record straight on why this period was flat: the counteractive effect of aerosol pollution prevented higher temperatures. When the pollution controls kicked in, and CO2 levels continued to increase, the long term warming trend continued and spiked.

It's unclear why some people can't grasp this simple concept, but desire to has a lot to do with it. Slate-wiping political ideology ensures a small percentage of the public won't ever accept the facts. This is why instead of arguing what to do about AGW, a debatable proposition, we have backslid into arguing if AGW is real. The fringe minority is controlling the message in the public square. That has to change.

"It is easy to see how politically biased the Arends rant is, for example, when one considers that he buttresses his argument for warmism with... a call to get off of oil because of Muslim terrorism? So, will we see Arends as others like him pushing for opening the colossal domestic U.S. oil reserves that probably lie offshore in the Atlantic and Pacific coats, currently off-limits to oil exploration and jobs? What about the massive oil shales in Montana, the proven oil Alaska?"

According to the Energy Information Administration, if all lower 48 states drilling was allowed, there would be not discernible increase in production for over a decade. By 2030, there would be a 3 percent increase in our domestic production, which would amount to around or a little under 2 percent of the percentages of oil that we currently import. Neglible, and nothing for 2 decades.Not sure how much Alaska adds, claims are all over the place, but the most credible ones (again the EIA) think is around the lower 48 or a little more.

Also, there are many reasons for getting of of oil -- and no real reason for staying on it. (One, and only one, if one accepts the presumption that we can't positively grow without oil, and that growth -- rather than the type of growth, is dependent upon using oil.)

There is no reason for being reliant upon foreign oil, and sending hundreds of billions overseas to boot, often to unfriendly regimes. Switching our passenger fleet over to plug in hybrids alone would undermine the need for close to 2/3 of of the oil we import (rather than 2 percent of it), and that's assuming a static model where there are no further developments in vehicles. (Transpo' accounts for 68% of our oil use, we import 60%).

Oil is also highly polluting aside from co2. And then there is co2 itself: What we are doing is taking carbon that was sequestered over hundreds of millions of years (as the earth,correspondingly,tended to cool) and releasing it in a geologic instant, quickly putting us back to the levels of GHG in Global Warming Potential equivalents (GWPe) in part because we are increasing other GHG as well -- that existed when much of the land was underwater, and the climate radically different (and hotter.)

It pretty much makes a lot of sense to try and develop incentives right now, not tomorrow, to use less and less of the stuff (which won't happen on its own -- as George Bush noted, we are 'addicted' to it) and incentives to develop, implement and use smarter energies.

Also, note there is a lot of confusion over the issue of "climate change" from co2, and the inherent idea that since we don't see oceans 100 fee higher, and the earth becoming jungly and scorched, that therefore it doesn't work this way.

Actually the way it doesn't work is on our human time frame, so we naturally over focus on the relevance of what is a human time frame (where a few years are said to tell us so much) versus a geologic time frame. Climate shifts rapidly on a geologic time frame (or can) but that might mean 10 years, it might mean 90 -- but the point is the effect of increased GHG levels is something that will build over time, particularly as oceans retain heat (Revkin promised a post on sea heat levels) -- an inordinately slow process, and the ultimate driver of climate. It is not a simple equation of tomorrow we make GHG levels X amount and the climate is immediately Z shape in response.

Re: wmar, #10

The charts you use show the 3/4-degree C "baseline" rise in temps that is wholly consistent with the hockey stick paradigm. Just because the scale is flattened doesn't change the data. That baseline rise is expected with increased CO2 in the atmosphere.

It's not a heat-island effect ... the data has been adjusted for such bias, and the Arctic is warming faster than the temperate zone.

It's not solar variation: there is no correlation of any significant length in recent decades.

Under the status quo, we should expect at least another one-degree baseline rise during the next century, throwing us even farther into uncharted temperature territory than we are currently.

Unless someone can demonstrate that temperatures fluctuated much more between the MWP and the LIA, thus minimizing the import of the hockey stick?
